# ETSI Domain Interoperability: Updated Ontology Entry

## Academic Context

- Interoperability fundamentals and definitions
  - The ability of different systems and organisations to work together effectively, encompassing both technical and semantic dimensions[4]
  - Technical interoperability concerns data exchange mechanisms, protocols, and system integration[4]
  - Semantic interoperability addresses shared understanding of data through vocabularies, ontologies, and metadata[4]
  - Foundational principle of FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable) digital objects[4]
- Evolution from metaverse-specific concept to cross-domain infrastructure
  - ETSI's Technical Committee on Data Solutions (TC DATA) now focuses on distributed data solutions, quality metrics, and trusted digital frameworks[3]
  - Shift towards practical, well-documented solutions and adoption of common standards across disciplines[4]

## Current Landscape (2025)

- Standards development and regulatory alignment
  - ETSI TS 103 878-2 V1.1.1 (May 2025) establishes interoperability test descriptions for roaming and non-roaming scenarios, including IPv6 address allocation, DNS/DNS64 address allocation, NAT64 prefix discovery, and Internet server access[1]
  - EU Data Act Article 35 mandates open interoperability specifications and harmonised standards for data processing services, with requirements for achieving interoperability between different services and enhancing portability of digital assets[2]
  - Central Union standards repository for interoperability of data processing services now operational[2]
- Key technical frameworks and components
  - ETSI NGSI-LD (Next Generation Service Interfaces) and SAREF (Smart Applications Reference Ontology) enable connected infrastructures to exchange and interpret data across platforms[3][8]
  - EOSC Interoperability Framework (EOSC IF) and Cross-Domain Interoperability Framework (CDIF) provide assessment and implementation guidance[4]
  - Core EOSC components include Metadata Schema and Crosswalk Registry (MSCR), PID Graph, Data Type Registry (DTR), and Compliance Assessment Toolkit (CAT)[4]
- Quality metrics and trustworthiness standards
  - ETSI TC DATA developing quality metrics for data trustworthiness focusing on completeness, accuracy, bias, integrity, and reliability[3]
  - Particular emphasis on AI-driven contexts where data health assessment is critical[3]
- Accessibility and inclusive communication
  - ETSI ES 204 009 V1.1.1 (August 2025) specifies interoperable total conversation services combining voice, real-time text, and sign language-supportive video communication[6]
  - Compliance with European Accessibility Act requirements for modality conversion and emergency communications[6]

## Research & Literature

- Primary standards and technical specifications
  - ETSI TS 103 878-2 V1.1.1 (2025-05): Interoperability Test Descriptions for roaming and non-roaming scenarios. Available from ETSI Technical Standards repository.
  - ETSI TR 104 409 V1.1.1 (2025-06): Data Interoperability and Data Exchange specifications aligned with EU Data Act requirements. Available from ETSI Technical Reports repository.
  - ETSI TS 133 310 V18.8.0 (2025-10): Security architecture for inter-domain interoperability using certificate-based cross-certifications. Available from ETSI Technical Standards repository.
  - ETSI ES 204 009 V1.1.1 (2025-08): Functional and accessibility requirements for interoperable total conversation services. Available from ETSI European Standards repository.
  - ETSI TS 103 264 V4.1.1 (2025-03): Smart Applications REFerence Ontology (SAREF) for enabling interoperability between solutions from different providers. Available from ETSI Technical Standards repository.
- Cross-domain research initiatives
  - FAIR-IMPACT Project (2025): Guidelines for usage of components for technical and semantic interoperability in cross-domain use cases within the European Open Science Cloud. Deliverable D6.1 provides actionable guidance for achieving semantic and technical interoperability, particularly in cross-domain research and data integration contexts.
  - Emphasis on practical metrics and checklists aligned with EOSC Interoperability Framework and Cross-Domain Interoperability Framework[4]
- Emerging research directions
  - Landscape analysis of existing data standards to identify gaps in coverage of essential technical requirements for secure and interoperable distributed data sharing[3]
  - Convergence of ETSI NGSI-LD and SAREF frameworks for seamless data exchange across smart cities, IoT systems, and connected infrastructures[3]
  - Data governance use-cases generated by sensing technologies, informing standards for privacy, trust, and interoperability across urban environments, manufacturing, and transport networks[3]
  - Role of artificial intelligence in supporting future scalability and automation of interoperability solutions[4]

## UK Context

- Standards participation and influence
  - UK organisations participate in ETSI technical committees through BSI (British Standards Institution) representation, contributing to development of interoperability standards affecting UK digital infrastructure[3]
  - UK compliance with EU Data Act requirements through alignment with ETSI harmonised standards, particularly relevant for organisations operating across UK-EU borders[2]
- North England innovation and implementation
  - Manchester's digital innovation ecosystem increasingly adopts ETSI standards for smart city infrastructure and IoT interoperability, particularly through local authority digital transformation initiatives
  - Leeds City Council and regional combined authorities implementing interoperable data governance frameworks aligned with ETSI specifications for transport and urban planning applications
  - Newcastle and the North East's growing focus on data sovereignty and trusted data collaboration through adoption of ETSI-compliant frameworks, particularly in manufacturing and industrial IoT contexts
  - Sheffield's advanced manufacturing sector utilising SAREF ontology for cross-platform equipment interoperability and predictive maintenance systems
- Academic contributions
  - UK universities contributing to FAIR-IMPACT and similar cross-domain interoperability research initiatives through EOSC participation[4]
  - Research emphasis on practical implementation of semantic interoperability in energy domain and smart applications[9]

## Future Directions

- Regulatory and governance evolution
  - Continued alignment of ETSI standards with EU Data Act implementation, with anticipated updates to harmonised standards repository through 2025-2026[2]
  - Expansion of digital wallet and smart contract standards aligned with European Digital Identity Regulation (eIDAS2)[3]
- Technical advancement priorities
  - Development of automated interoperability assessment tools leveraging artificial intelligence for scalability and efficiency[4]
  - Enhanced convergence between NGSI-LD and SAREF frameworks to support increasingly complex cross-sector data exchange scenarios[3]
  - Standardisation of data governance frameworks for emerging sensing technologies across urban, manufacturing, and transport domains[3]
- Cross-sectoral collaboration
  - Continued collaboration between ETSI, CEN (European Committee for Standardisation), and CENELEC (European Committee for Electrotechnical Standardisation) to address technical aspects of EU Data Act[3]
  - Expansion of interoperability frameworks beyond traditional ICT sectors into energy, healthcare, and environmental monitoring domains[9]
- Practical implementation challenges
  - Balancing semantic precision with technical simplicity remains an ongoing tension in cross-domain implementations
  - Ensuring backward compatibility whilst adopting new standards presents particular challenges for established infrastructure operators
